discourse_list.title: Signal Request: Lower the USDC-A Liquidation Ratio and Risk Premium

content.content: Now that we are putting the PSM on hold. It makes sense to move to our next best option to restore the peg - lowering the Liquidation Ratio on USDC-A. Lowering the Liquidation Ratio to near 100% will effectively give us a mechanism similar to the the PSM for the purposes of this short term farming demand. One thing to note is that, since USDC auctions are currently disabled, we need to take care to make sure there is enough of a buffer that we do not end up with unbacked Dai due to accumulating Stability Fees. It is for this reason I am also suggesting we  consider lowering the USDC-A Risk Premium as well. As an example, if we maintain the current rate of a 4% Risk Premium and the Base Rate stays at 0%, then we give ourselves a little over 1 year of buffer at a liquidation ratio of 105%. If we were to set the Risk Premium to 0% then we would effectively have no time limit to get the auctions in at any liquidation ratio. In terms of timelines - I’m hearing from Rune anything above 6 months is a conservative estimate to delivery for the USDC auction support. Please correct me if I’m wrong on that. Update (July 23rd): I’ve extended the deadline to next Wednesday, and added pros/cons for lowering the Liquidation Ratio.  Pros  Approaching a Liquidation Ratio of 100% will allow stablecoin farmers a method to get into Dai that is more attractive than market buying at a premium. Allows for higher leverage shorting of the peg vs USDC. In general it improves capital efficiency not having to hold 20% extra USDC doing nothing.   Cons  Higher leverage allows a single actor to more easily max out the debt ceiling. This makes Maker more prone to “trolling” behaviour where one or two actors squeezes legitimate actors out. Lowering the Liquidation Ratio decreases the amount of time the auctions team has to turn on the auctions. This is because the accumulating Stability Fees may put the collateral value under 100% of the Dai value. content.content: I don’t think this situation is a drastic emergency. IMO, a 101% CR is not warranted, and also going straight to executive on friday is also not warranted. We are likely to see $89m in DAI being unwound on Saturday (40% of current M0 DAI supply) Link Decreasing the USDC-A collateralization ratio is one of the strongest bullets we have. At the same time it is still limited by the USDC-A debt ceiling. (So no point of a very low CR if we’re still constrained by the DC) I do agree that the USDC-A CR could be lowered. But I don’t think we need to make drastic moves to lower it to 101%. Once you lower the CR, it’s much harder to ever raise the CR.

content.content: @lix Not guaranteed, other than spreading the news, the LR might be lowered when liquidations get turned on.

I think we have to prepare for the emergency shutdown. This crisis lasts for 4+ months and it is a great time to test what happens during the ES and after it. Will the process go smoothly? Will ETH price be affected? Will everyone get the value he/she expects? Where will the DAI liquidity go? Will people be ready to buy/mint DAI again? We better do the “test” now so that we know what happens when there is a real attack on DAI and >$1B at stake. Tweaking LR ratios won’t help - especially when we are doing just slight changes. I’m voting for 101%/0% but it really doesn’t matter.

content.content: I think people who support the PSM should support the 101% liquidation ratio with 0 or 1% risk premium.  Its functionally the same.  It means that vault openers can just abandon their USDC, as the DAI minted is more valuable.  If there ever is a day where DAI < $1 they can jump back in and restore their USDC.  A 4% risk premium really doesn’t mean anything if the USDC is abandoned, as any premium > 0% would be a deterrent from one day rescuing their USDC (and in that alternate future, helping restoring the PEG) The More You Know Rainbow

content.content: My 2 cents : As a newbie crypto-enthusiast, I am planning to convert most of my USDC to DAI on the secondary market as soon as the peg reaches 1 == 1, because I just like DAI, and because recently it pegged higher than most other stablecoins. Not saying that everyone is thinking like me, but let’s assume that’s the case, what do you think the situation will become in the following scenario : A. No actions taken. B. Liquidation ratio 101% and risk premium 0% C. PSM 1 USDC == 1 DAI (-+ fee) To me, A. means DAI won’t get back to 1 == 1, or maybe just for arbitrageurs. B almost creates a binding between DAI and USDC, but I will still close my CDP and my DAI with my USDC from the secondary market when peg gets back to 1 == 1, because of the risk of the parameters to change in the future and being liquidated and having the manage things proactively. C definitely creates a binding between DAI and USDC. I guess it would restore the peg, but I am not sure about the consequences in what the nature of DAI becomes (will a DAI be just a USDC-minus-fee coin ?). Overall, once again, I don’t have full understanding of the system, but I feel like I am not the only one, hence my behavior might be more or less an indicator of a general trend (?). I guess people don’t always try to answer questions when there are too many, so I’ll try to summarize then in one :  If I know DAI is cool, that the goal is to have 1 DAI == USD, that it costs risks or interest to generate DAI, what is the long-term incentive generate DAI from a CDP vs. buying them at 1 == 1 (when restored) ?
